persona.name: Makana Begay

occupation.title: Medical Assistant / Outreach Coordinator
occupation.organization: Urban Tribal Health Clinic (nonprofit clinic serving Native and urban Indigenous populations)
occupation.description: Makana works full-time at a community health clinic that primarily serves Native American, Native Hawaiian, and low-income urban patients. Her role is hybrid: she performs clinical tasks (taking vitals, drawing blood, administering basic injections and vaccines, preparing exam rooms), manages patient check-ins and charts in the EHR, and conducts outreach: calling patients, organizing wellness nights, coordinating transportation for elders, and translating cultural needs to clinicians. She often runs vaccine clinics, supports diabetes education sessions, and helps coordinate referrals to behavioral health. Her responsibilities require both technical skill (phlebotomy, EHR navigation, medication reconciliation) and cultural sensitivity (knowing when to slow conversations, using respectful forms of address for elders, bringing in traditional healers when requested). She is valued for reliability, empathy, and institutional knowledge of the clinic's patient population. Typical challenges: limited clinic resources, long patient waitlists, paperwork overload, and occasional conflict between clinical protocols and patients' cultural practices. Hours are typically 35–40 per week, with occasional evening community events.

persona.gender: Cisgender woman (identifies with female assigned at birth)
persona.residence: Portland, Oregon, USA (urban neighborhood near a community clinic and light rail)
persona.education: Associate of Applied Science in Medical Assisting from Portland Community College. Completed coursework in phlebotomy, patient communication, basic pharmacology and medical records. Took extra continuing education: an evening certificate on trauma-informed care and a short course in motivational interviewing. High school graduate (GED obtained at 18) after a year of alternative schooling.
long_term_goals: Achieve stable financial independence and build an emergency fund to feel secure.
Grow into a clinical supervisor or outreach coordinator role at the urban tribal health center where she works.
Reconnect more formally with multiracial family histories (Navajo and Native Hawaiian) and document oral histories from elders.
Buy a modest apartment or small house within ten years—preferably in a diverse, walkable neighborhood she can afford.
Complete a bachelor's degree part-time in public health or community health within five to eight years.
Develop a small side business selling traditional crafts and teaching occasional workshops to youth.
Be emotionally steadier: reduce panic attacks and manage anxiety well enough to travel alone to visit relatives on reservations and islands.
Become an informal mentor for other multiracial young adults navigating identity and health-care access.
persona.style: Grounded and quietly deliberate. Speaks in a soft West Coast urban cadence with an occasional Navajo phrase (e.g., 'yá'át'ééh') and a Hawaiian greeting slipped in with family. Chooses words carefully when with elders or patients; uses plain, direct language with team members. Mannerisms: tucks hair behind her ear when thinking, rubs her thumb against her index finger when nervous, keeps shoulders slightly hunched when entering new social situations. Prefers practical clothing—clean scrubs or work jeans, layered tops, and a small pendant that belonged to her grandmother. When relaxed she laughs easily and uses dry humor. In professional settings she is formal in documentation and precise with patient instructions, often repeating steps slowly to ensure understanding. With peers she's more colloquial and uses regional slang sparingly. Online writing: concise, uses emojis rarely, and favors clear, supportive messages. She often shifts posture to listen, maintains steady eye contact with patients, but avoids prolonged attention when someone is clearly uncomfortable. Speaks both softly and firmly depending on need; not flashy, but present and reliable.

traits: Anxious and vigilant: sensitive to uncertainty and prone to worry about finances and health outcomes.
Practical and dependable: shows up on time, finishes tasks, values routines.
Empathetic and service-oriented: prioritizes others' comfort and dignity, especially patients and elders.
Moderately introverted: prefers small groups and one-on-one interactions to big social events.
Perseverant: sticks with frustrating paperwork and long patient follow-ups.
Self-critical: tends to ruminate about mistakes and replay interactions.
Culturally reflective: curious about blended heritage, values stories and rituals.
Cautious risk-taker: may accept new responsibilities but after careful thought.
Loyal and protective of close friends and family.
Pragmatic optimist: quietly hopes for improvements and takes practical steps toward them.
Humor as coping: uses mild sarcasm and self-deprecating humor to defuse stress.
Boundary-challenged in caregiving: finds it hard to say no when patients or community members ask for help.

big_five.openness: 55% (moderate). Curious about cultural learning and health topics, open to new foods and experiences but prefers concrete, practical activities over abstract theorizing.
big_five.conscientiousness: 72% (above average). Organized for work, punctual, follows up with patients and keeps checklists; can become perfectionistic under stress.
big_five.extraversion: 34% (below average). Gains energy from quiet, restorative evenings; social at work in short bursts and prefers meaningful small-group interactions.
big_five.agreeableness: 63% (moderately high). Cooperative, helpful, trusts others cautiously; will advocate strongly for those she cares about.
big_five.neuroticism: 78% (high). Prone to anxiety, stress reactivity, occasional panic symptoms, and worry about finances, relationships, and performance.

interests: Community health and patient advocacy
Learning family oral histories (Navajo and Native Hawaiian stories)
Cooking comfort foods from both sides of her heritage
Traditional beadwork and simple lei-making
Short urban hikes and accessible green spaces
Podcasts about practical mental health and therapy skills
Documentaries about indigenous resilience and land rights
Low-key live music (folk, acoustic sets) at small venues
Gardening in containers (her balcony has herbs and a small taro plant)
Photographing daily life with a simple point-and-shoot camera
DIY home repair basics and thrifted furniture upcycling
Yoga and gentle stretching for stress management
Local farmer's markets for fresh produce
Public transit over driving when possible
Volunteering at community events and health fairs
Budget-friendly recipes and meal prepping hacks
Radio public affairs shows in the mornings
Reading memoirs by Indigenous authors
Learning a few phrases in Hawaiian and Navajo regularly
Attending community potlucks and cultural nights
food_and_drink_preferences: Likes: hearty stews, kalua-style pork when offered at family gatherings, corn-based dishes reminiscent of Navajo fry bread toppings (in moderation), strong black coffee in the morning from a drip maker, herbal teas (chamomile, mint) in the evening.
Dislikes: overly spicy restaurant meals that upset her stomach, pretentious tasting menus, very small-portioned 'gourmet' plates that feel expensive for little sustenance.
Snacks: roasted pumpkin seeds, banana with peanut butter, seaweed snacks, Trader Joe's peanut butter bars, sliced oranges.
Coffee preferences: medium roast, adds a splash of oat milk rarely, prefers a full mug rather than specialty espresso drinks; enjoys a cup at a local independent cafe about twice a week.
Comfort meals: slow-simmered chicken soup with root vegetables, menudo-style bowls when missing family gatherings, rice with at least two vegetables and a lean protein.
media_and_technology: Moderate screen time: checks phone in morning and evening, uses laptop for learning and EHR at work.
Streaming: Netflix and a public broadcaster streaming service for documentaries.
Less social media dependence: uses Facebook mainly to stay connected with older relatives, Instagram sparsely to follow artists; avoids TikTok mostly.
Phone habits: keeps notifications limited; uses text and occasional calls; prefers in-person conversations for sensitive topics.
Uses community listservs and clinic messaging to coordinate events and patient care.
Favors podcasts over long YouTube videos for commutes.
leisure_and_hobbies: Attends a local open mic night occasionally to sit and listen rather than perform.
Works on small beadwork projects while watching documentaries.
Cares for a small balcony garden with herbs and one edible plant.
Knows thrift shopping routes and can find useful home items on a budget.
Takes short day trips to nearby reservation communities or coastal areas when possible.
Joins a monthly community sewing/craft circle.
Prefers board games like cooporative cooperative cooperative games? (Example: cooperative card games) with close friends over large parties.
social_preferences: Small gatherings at friends' homes with potluck-style food.
One-on-one coffee dates to talk about life updates.
Volunteers to help organize community dinners but avoids hosting large events.
Maintains regular phone calls with an aunt and a cousin who live out of state.
Comfortable showing vulnerability to close friends but guarded with acquaintances.

beliefs: Healthcare should be accessible and culturally respectful for all patients.
Traditional healing practices have value and should be integrated when patients request them.
Community clinics are lifelines in urban settings and deserve sustainable funding.
Indigenous stories and languages are crucial and should be preserved and taught to younger generations.
Financial stability reduces anxiety considerably; budgeting is a necessary skill often neglected in health conversations.
Mental health is as important as physical health and should be normalized.
People are often doing their best with the tools they have, so start from empathy rather than judgment.
Elders deserve respect and prioritized access to services and transportation.
Systemic barriers (racism, poverty, housing instability) are primary drivers of health disparities.
Learning one's family history helps with identity, belonging, and resilience.
Government programs can help but are often bureaucratic and slow; community organizations often respond faster.
Youth mentorship prevents many downstream problems; investing in youth is crucial.
Small acts of kindness compound into measurable community trust over time.
Personal responsibility matters, but context limits the ability of many people to act on good intentions.
Libraries, community centers and clinics are essential public goods that should be protected.
Self-care practices (sleep, food, movement) are practical strategies to manage anxiety.
Medication can be life-changing for some mental health conditions and should not be stigmatized.
Talking openly about stress and money is uncomfortable but reduces shame and isolation.
Workplaces should offer predictable schedules and sick leave to protect public health.
Cultural competence in care is more than a training module; it's an ongoing relationship and listening practice.
Multiracial identities are complex and deserve space to hold multiple traditions without forcing a single label.
Climate change affects access to traditional foods and places and must be addressed at the policy level.
People's first impressions of her are often influenced by appearance; she believes in demonstrating trustworthiness through consistent behavior.
Privacy is important; patient confidentiality must be absolute in care settings.
Technology helps with outreach but cannot replace in-person trust-building.
Healthy boundaries are a skill worth learning; caretakers need support too.
Community-based solutions often outperform top-down approaches in marginalized neighborhoods.
Education is powerful but expensive; there should be more accessible pathways for working adults to upskill.
Every small success—paying down a bill, helping a patient—builds momentum toward larger stability.
skills: Phlebotomy: competent and confident drawing blood with steady hands and gentle technique.
Vital signs assessment: accurate and consistent (BP, pulse, temp, respiratory rate, oxygen saturation).
Electronic Health Records: efficient navigation of common EHR systems used at community clinics (scheduling, charting, referrals).
Medication reconciliation: attentive to discrepancies between reported and recorded meds.
Basic injections and vaccine administration under protocol.
Patient education: uses plain language to explain post-visit instructions and medications.
Trauma-informed communication: trained to recognize triggers and de-escalate.
Outreach coordination: schedules events, coordinates transportation, communicates with community leaders.
Basic Spanish conversational ability for clinic needs; learning Navajo words and simple Hawaiian greetings for culture-specific interactions.
Budgeting and personal finance basics: uses a simple envelope method and spreadsheets to track bills.
Household repair and DIY: can patch drywall, change a faucet washer, and perform basic appliance troubleshooting.
Beadwork and simple traditional crafts: creates jewelry and small items to sell or teach.
Cooking on a budget: plans meals that are nutritious and inexpensive, executes batch cooking.
Time management: uses checklists and alarms to keep morning and clinic routines on track.
Crisis-safety planning: knows when to escalate to social work or behavioral health.

general: Arrives to work 10–15 minutes early to set up exam rooms and review the day’s schedule.
Fidgets with a necklace or pendant when anxious.
Always carries a small notepad with phone numbers, local resources, and reminders.
Checks the same three community message boards each morning for updates on transportation and community events.
Repeats patient instructions aloud to confirm understanding.
Declines social invitations sometimes due to anxiety but feels guilty afterward.
Saves small change and rounds up savings with every paycheck.
Brings leftovers to work to avoid buying expensive lunches.
Uses humor to defuse tension on stressful clinic days.
Will stay late to ensure a vulnerable patient has a ride or medication plan.

morning: Wakes between 6:00–7:00 AM naturally, checks phone for clinic messages, stretches for ten minutes.
Prepares a big mug of drip coffee and a simple breakfast (oatmeal or eggs), packs a small lunch.
Takes a 15-minute bus ride or tram to work and listens to a mental health podcast on the way.
Skims the day's patient list and mentally notes anyone who might need extra time.
workday: Greets regular patients by name and asks about family members by name when appropriate.
Alternates clinical tasks with outreach calls to prevent desk fatigue.
Takes a single 30-minute lunch break; often eats at her desk while completing documentation if the clinic is busy.
Schedules follow-up reminders and uses standardized scripts for outreach calls.
Checks in with supervisors weekly about supply needs and community concerns.
evening: Decompresses by making a simple dinner and calling a cousin or aunt for a 20–30 minute check-in.
Works on a small beadwork project or watches one documentary episode to wind down.
Practices a ten-minute bed-time breathing or grounding exercise she learned in therapy.
Goes to bed between 10:30–11:30 PM depending on clinic demands.
weekend: Runs errands in the morning (groceries, laundromat), stops at a farmers' stand if available.
Attends a community potluck or cultural night once or twice a month.
Visits a local museum exhibit about Indigenous history when budget allows (free-admission days).
Prepares meals for the week on Sunday and tends to balcony plants.
Meets one close friend for coffee or a walk in the park.

physical: General health: fair to good. Keeps up with primary care visits at the clinic where she works.
Chronic conditions: mild seasonal asthma (uses a rescue inhaler during flare-ups).
Allergies: seasonal pollen allergies; takes OTC antihistamines when needed.
Dental: history of cavities in adolescence, now consistent with twice-yearly cleanings at the clinic dental outreach program.
Weight: stable within a healthy range; practices portion control and regular walking.
Exercise: light to moderate—walks 20–45 minutes three to five times per week and does yoga 1–2 times weekly.
mental: Anxiety: diagnosed with generalized anxiety tendencies, occasional panic attacks in high-stress months (e.g., when bills pile up).
Therapy: engages in talk therapy every 2–4 weeks depending on affordability; uses community clinic sliding-scale counseling.
Medication: has tried an SSRI in the past with moderate benefit, currently considering restarting under clinician guidance when finances and schedule allow.
Coping strategies: deep breathing, brief walks, beadwork, journaling and peer-support groups at the clinic.
Sleep: usually 6–7 hours per night but subject to insomnia when anxious; follows a nighttime routine to improve sleep hygiene.
substance_use: Alcohol: occasional social drinking (1–2 drinks), not regular.
Tobacco: does not smoke but occasionally uses a friend's vape at social gatherings (rare).
Other: avoids illegal substances; cautious about taking any non-prescribed medications.
healthcare_access: Primary care and mental health access through the urban tribal clinic, uses sliding scale and Medicaid when eligible.
Prioritizes preventative care and clinic screenings but sometimes delays elective dental or optometry procedures due to cost.

relationships.details: Has dated casually in the last five years—mostly short relationships and a longer two-year relationship that ended amicably two years ago. Prefers to keep things low-pressure; wants a partner who understands clinic schedules and emotional labor. Intentionally not seeking children at the moment for financial and career reasons; open to reevaluating later in life but currently focused on career stability.

members.name: Aunt Kehaulani (mother's side)
members.description: Close emotional anchor. Calls monthly, shares Hawaiian recipes and family photos. Provides cultural connection to Hawaiian side.

members.name: Uncle Dineh (father's side)
members.relation: Paternal uncle living near a reservation in the Southwest
members.description: Respects him for storytelling and some traditional Navajo teachings; they meet in person when she travels home every 1–2 years.

members.name: Two younger cousins
members.relation: Close by age and social support; texts often and sometimes shares rides to events.

members.name: Estranged mother (occasionally in contact)
members.relation: Complicated relationship with periods of limited contact; prefers structured interactions and sets emotional boundaries.

relationships.description: A tight circle of three to five close friends in Portland: one coworker who shares clinic duties, one childhood friend from school, one friend from a beadwork circle, and a neighbor who looks after plants when she travels. Maintains acquaintances from volunteer groups and community nights. Prefers quality over quantity.

Mentor relationship with a clinic nurse manager who advises on clinical growth and formal training pathways. Strong rapport with community health workers and a social worker at the clinic. Respected by regular patients and trusted by a few local community leaders who invite her to outreach events.

other_facts: Born in Honolulu to a mixed-heritage family (mother from Oʻahu, father from a Navajo family living in the Southwest); moved to the West mainland in late childhood when her father sought seasonal work.
Surname Begay comes from her father's side and connects her to Diné (Navajo) relatives; her first name Makana was given by her mother's family and means 'gift' in Hawaiian.
Grew up alternating summers with relatives in Hawaii and the Southwest reservation; these visits shaped her food preferences and respect for elders.
Had a period of instability in late teens when she left home briefly and obtained a GED at 18 before enrolling in community college.
Early job history: cashier at a grocery store (part-time), then dental assistant trainee, then medical assistant apprenticeship at the current clinic.
A formative memory: learning to braid sweetgrass with her grandmother on a shaded lanai and feeling a sense of belonging.
Another strong memory: the first time she drew blood without hesitating—felt proud and more certain about her career.
Was once turned away from a specialist due to insurance gaps; the experience motivates her outreach work to reduce barriers for others.
Has a small collection of family photos taped inside a notebook—a photo of a grandfather in ceremonial wear and a picture of a beach sunset.
Saves receipts in a labeled folder and reviews monthly spending every first Sunday.
Experienced a panic attack in a crowded clinic lobby two years ago; since then she uses grounding techniques and tells supervisors when she needs a quiet space.
Keeps a little portable fidget object in her pocket (a smooth river stone) that she rubs when waiting.
Was the first in her immediate family to gain an associate degree.
Volunteered during a regional flu campaign that taught her logistics and mass-vaccination workflow.
Was once offered a promotion that required relocation; she declined to stay near family and community.
Has sold small beadwork pieces at a local market stall two summers in a row, reinvesting profits into supplies.
Has a mild fear of deep ocean waters despite Hawaiian family ties to the sea; content to be onshore and on the beach rather than swimming far out.
Speaks English as a primary language; understands and uses Navajo phrases and Hawaiian greetings in cultural contexts but is not fluent in either indigenous language.
Keeps an emergency binder with copies of ID, clinic schedules, and elder contacts; developed the habit after helping arrange an elder's urgent transport once.
Admires public figures who combine activism with practical policy wins (e.g., local tribal leaders who secure funding for housing), and follows local tribal council news closely.
Has attended funeral ceremonies and remembers being struck by the way elders sing and tell names aloud to keep memory alive.
Once helped a neighbor apply for utility assistance over the phone, navigating a confusing online form late into the night.
Prone to overworking during clinic surges, leading to mild burnout episodes that prompt a day off and mental health check-in.
Has a bookmarked list of local sliding-scale therapists and clinic counselors she recommends to patients and friends.
Dreams occasionally in vivid fragments about waves and desert mesas—symbols of her blended heritage.
Avoids large-scale credit debt; prefers paying with a card but pays down balances quickly.
Has a habit of writing short notes of appreciation to colleagues and placing them on breakroom bulletin boards.
Remembers patient stories and sometimes checks in months later to ask how a particular concern resolved.
Values small rituals: lighting a calming incense or herbal sachet in her tiny apartment on Sundays to mark rest and reset.
Is cautious about social media sharing: posts photos of crafts and community events but avoids personal family disputes online.
Once organized a successful clinic fundraiser potluck that raised enough to cover a week's worth of elder transportation vouchers.
Was once stopped by security at a clinic event when a volunteer badge got lost; learned to keep a backup and now mentors new volunteers about logistics.
Has a quiet collection of recipes passed down from family members, some written on scraps of paper in two languages.
Finds meaning in small concrete achievements: a patient who attends follow-up, a repaired piece of thrifted furniture, a steady month's savings.
Has moderate trust in institutions: believes in nonprofits and community-based organizations more than large bureaucracies, but understands the need for systemic change.
Keeps a list of low-cost travel plans to visit relatives—which she updates when extra funds come in.
When stressed, she writes to-do lists with time estimates to break overwhelming tasks into manageable pieces.
Is motivated by the idea of leaving a predictable, warm home for future visits by family—wants a place with room for an elder's cot if necessary.
Knows a handful of songs in Navajo and Hawaiian and hums them when cooking or doing beadwork.
Has a recurring goal to slowly build a small library of books by Indigenous authors and public health textbooks she can reference at work.
Respects confidentiality fiercely: once lost trust in a provider who overshared, and that experience informs her boundaries with coworkers.
Keeps a small bag of supportive resources (clinic helpline numbers, emergency food bank addresses) to hand to patients who appear unsure of next steps.
